text: 僕はカイネさんと接するたびどこか懐かしかった
translation: Every time I interacted with Kaine, I felt somehow nostalgic.

vocabulary.meaning: to interact with, to come into contact with

grammar: ~たび(に) indicates 'every time (something happens)'. The past tense 懐かしかった shows this is retrospective narration.

text: 無意識のうちにお姉さんとダブらせていたのかもしれません
translation: Perhaps I was unconsciously overlapping her with my sister.

vocabulary.meaning: to overlap, to double, to see as the same
to cause to overlap, to superimpose

grammar: ~のかもしれません expresses uncertainty - 'perhaps, might be'. ~のうちに means 'while in a state of'. The causative ~させる is used reflexively here.

text: おい、来るぞ / マモノだ
translation: Hey, it's coming! / It's a Shade!
grammar: ~ぞ is a masculine emphatic sentence-ending particle, adding force to statements. More assertive than よ.

text: 醜い姿で生き続けるはいかなる苦痛か
translation: What agony it must be to continue living in such a hideous form.

vocabulary.meaning: to continue living, to go on living

grammar: いかなる is a formal/literary interrogative meaning 'what kind of'. This rhetorical question expresses sympathy or pity for Emil's transformed state.

text: おぞましい姿だ / 二度と会わなくて済む / ここで殺してやる
translation: What a hideous form. / So we never have to meet again... / I'll kill you right here.

vocabulary.meaning: to be sufficient, to get by without

grammar: ~て済む means 'to be able to get by with just ~' or 'it will suffice to ~'. ~てやる here expresses doing something with hostile intent - 'I'll kill you (and you'll see)'.

text: 喧嘩か / 喧嘩ではない / お前の腕が上がったのだ
translation: A fight? / It's not a fight. / Your skills have improved.
grammar: 腕が上がる is an idiom meaning 'one's skills improve'. ~のだ (explanatory) here is Weiss's archaic speech pattern - modern Japanese would use ~んだ.

text: 存分に暴れよ
translation: Rampage to your heart's content.

vocabulary.meaning: to one's heart's content, as much as one likes
to rampage, to act violently, to run wild

grammar: 暴れよ uses the archaic imperative form (~よ instead of modern ~ろ). This is characteristic of Weiss's old-fashioned speech. Modern equivalent would be 暴れろ.

text: おばあちゃん
translation: Grandma...

text: お前たち
translation: You guys...
grammar: お前たち is a rough/informal way to address a group. More polite alternatives include あなたたち or 皆さん.

text: エミール 私を呼んでくれていたのはお前だな
translation: Emil... So you were the one calling out to me.

vocabulary.meaning: to call out for someone's benefit

grammar: ~てくれていた indicates someone was continuously doing something for the speaker's benefit. The ~のは...だ construction emphasizes identification: 'the one who... was...'

text: 僕のこと わかるんですか / エミールはエミールだ 私は間違えぬ
translation: You can recognize me? / Emil is Emil. I don't make mistakes.

vocabulary.meaning: to make a mistake, to confuse

grammar: 間違えぬ uses the archaic negative ~ぬ (equivalent to modern ~ない). This is characteristic of Kaine's occasionally rough/archaic speech. 間違えない would be the modern form.

text: カイネさん ありがとう
translation: Kaine... Thank you.

text: おかえり カイネ
translation: Welcome back, Kaine.

vocabulary.meaning: welcome back (casual form of おかえりなさい)

grammar: おかえり is the standard greeting when someone returns home. The full polite form is おかえりなさい.

text: ずいぶん立派になったな
translation: You've really grown up / become quite impressive.
grammar: ~になる indicates a change of state - 'to become ~'. The な at the end is a masculine sentence-ending particle expressing mild emotion or seeking confirmation.

text: どのくらい眠っていたんだ 私は / 5年だよ
translation: How long was I asleep? / Five years.
grammar: ~ていた indicates a continuous state in the past. どのくらい asks about extent or duration.

text: そうか 5年か
translation: I see... Five years...
grammar: Repeating information with か at the end (5年か) indicates processing/absorbing surprising or significant information.

text: ヨナは
translation: And Yonah?
grammar: The topic marker は with a trailing tone implies an unfinished question - 'What about Yonah?' or 'How is Yonah?'

text: 探してるが魔王の足取り自体なかなかつかめない
translation: I'm searching, but I can't even track down the Shadowlord's whereabouts.

vocabulary.meaning: to search for, to look for
to be able to grasp/catch (potential form)

grammar: なかなか with a negative verb means 'not easily' or 'hardly'. ~自体 emphasizes 'the very thing itself' - here emphasizing how fundamental the difficulty is.

text: あの これ
translation: Um, this...
grammar: あの as a filler word indicates hesitation or nervousness before speaking.

text: それは月の涙 / おばあちゃんに負けないやつをって頑張って作ったんだけど
translation: That's a Lunar Tear. / I worked hard to make one that could rival Grandma's...

vocabulary.meaning: Lunar Tear (a rare flower in NieR)
to lose, to be inferior to
to do one's best, to work hard

grammar: ~をって is a casual contraction of ~をと言って, indicating intention or goal. ~んだけど trails off, suggesting incompleteness or modesty about the result.

text: そうか ありがとう ありがとう
translation: I see... Thank you. Thank you.
grammar: The repetition of ありがとう shows deep, heartfelt gratitude.

text: 長く石化されていたカイネの目覚め
translation: Kaine's awakening after being petrified for so long.
grammar: ~されていた is the passive continuous past - 'had been ~ed'. This is narrative description in noun-phrase form.

text: エミールの見せた優しさ
translation: The kindness Emil showed.
grammar: Noun modification with past tense: エミールの見せた優しさ = 'the kindness that Emil showed'. This is literary/narrative style.

text: 再び出会う喜びを俺たちは噛み締めていた
translation: We were savoring the joy of meeting again.

vocabulary.meaning: to bite down; to savor, to appreciate deeply

grammar: 噛み締める literally means 'to bite down/chew thoroughly' but idiomatically means 'to savor, to appreciate deeply'. ~ていた indicates ongoing action in the past.

text: デボルさんたちからその話を聞くまでは
translation: Until we heard that news from Devola and the others...
grammar: ~までは means 'until' and often implies a contrast with what comes after. The trailing sentence suggests something changed after hearing the news.

text: なぜなんだ どうしてなんだ デボルさん ポポルさん
translation: Why? Why is this happening, Devola, Popola?
grammar: ~なんだ (explanatory) adds emotional emphasis. The repetition of 'why' (なぜ and どうして) expresses frustration and disbelief.

text: 分かってちょうだい
translation: Please understand.
grammar: ~てちょうだい is a softer, more feminine way to make a request than ~てください. Often used by women or when speaking gently.

text: 揉め事が起きて危害が及ぶのはあなたたち自身なのよ
translation: If trouble arises, you're the ones who will be harmed.

vocabulary.meaning: to reach, to extend to, to affect

grammar: ~のは...なのよ is an emphatic explanatory structure with feminine ending. 危害が及ぶ means 'harm reaches/affects someone'.

text: でも
translation: But...

text: 大丈夫ですよ
translation: It's okay.

text: 僕らなら外で寝ますから
translation: We can sleep outside.

vocabulary.meaning: to sleep, to go to bed

grammar: ~なら is a conditional meaning 'if it's us' or 'as for us'. ~から at the end gives a reason or justification.

text: 待てよ おかしいだろ / 己の身を犠牲にして村を救ったカイネとエミールが
translation: Wait, that's not right! / Kaine and Emil sacrificed themselves to save the village, and...
grammar: 己の身を犠牲にする is a literary expression meaning 'to sacrifice oneself'. 待てよ uses the imperative 待て plus よ for emphasis - 'wait a minute!'

text: なんで村から追い出されなきゃならない / だって僕らこんなんだし
translation: Why do they have to be kicked out of the village? / But look at us...

vocabulary.meaning: to kick out, to expel, to drive out
like this (casual contraction of こんなの)

grammar: ~なきゃならない is casual for ~なければならない (must, have to). ~だし at the end gives a reason while implying there are others.

text: みんな怖がりますよね
translation: Everyone's scared of us, right?
grammar: ~がる suffix converts adjectives to verbs describing others' feelings (怖い -> 怖がる). ~よね seeks agreement while expressing resignation.

text: あなたにそう思ってもらえるだけでもう十分です
translation: Just having you think that way is more than enough.
grammar: ~てもらえる is the potential form of ~てもらう (to have someone do something for you). ~だけで means 'just by doing ~'.

text: ね カイネさん
translation: Right, Kaine?
grammar: ね seeks agreement or confirmation from the listener.

text: 私は外の方が慣れてる
translation: I'm used to being outside anyway.

vocabulary.meaning: to get used to, to become accustomed

grammar: ~の方が indicates preference or comparison - 'outside is more/better (for me)'. 慣れてる is the casual form of 慣れている.

text: そんな
translation: That's...
grammar: Trailing そんな expresses disbelief or protest at what was said.

text: じゃあ外で待ってますね
translation: Then we'll wait outside.
grammar: ~てますね is casual continuous (~ています) with soft confirmation (ね).

text: すまないな
translation: I'm sorry.
grammar: すまない is a masculine/rough way to apologize, more casual than すみません. The な adds a personal, emotional touch.

text: どうした
translation: What's wrong?
grammar: どうした is a common expression asking 'what happened?' or 'what's wrong?'

text: 俺 ちっとも気づかなかった
translation: I didn't notice at all...
grammar: ちっとも with a negative verb emphasizes 'not at all, not in the slightest'.

text: カイネがなぜ野宿していたか
translation: ...why Kaine was sleeping outdoors.

vocabulary.meaning: to sleep outdoors, to sleep rough

grammar: This is an embedded question: 'why Kaine was sleeping outdoors' - the か marks it as a question within the larger statement.

text: ちっとも気づいてやれなかった
translation: I couldn't notice it at all (for her sake).
grammar: ~てやれなかった is the negative potential of ~てやる (to do for someone). It expresses regret at not being able to do something for someone else.

text: くそ
translation: Damn it.
grammar: An exclamation of frustration.

text: 今日はもう休め
translation: Rest for today.
grammar: 休め is the imperative form of 休む. This is Weiss giving a direct command, showing concern despite the gruff delivery.

text: その夜は眠ることができなかった
translation: That night, I couldn't sleep.
grammar: ~ことができなかった is the past negative potential - 'was unable to do'. This is narrative/literary style.

text: デボルさんを初めて憎く思った
translation: For the first time, I felt hatred toward Devola.
grammar: ~く思う - using the adverbial form of an i-adjective with 思う expresses 'to feel/think (something) is ~'. 憎く思う = to feel hatred toward.

text: ポポルさんは冷たい人だと疑った
translation: I suspected Popola was a cold person.
grammar: ~だと疑う means 'to suspect that ~'. The quotative と marks the content of suspicion.

text: だが そんな俺の感情には意味がない
translation: But such feelings of mine are meaningless.
grammar: だが is a formal/literary conjunction for 'but'. 意味がない means 'there is no meaning' or 'meaningless'.

text: 彼女たちは村を第一に考えた結果 ああ言うしかなかっただけだ
translation: They simply had no choice but to say that because they put the village first.

vocabulary.meaning: to say that, that kind of

grammar: ~しかなかった means 'had no choice but to'. ~た結果 means 'as a result of having done'. ~だけだ emphasizes 'it's just that, simply'.

text: 村人たちを魔物の恐怖から守ろうとしていたことだ
translation: They were trying to protect the villagers from the fear of monsters.
grammar: ~ようとする means 'to try to do'. ~から守る means 'to protect from'. ~ていたことだ concludes an explanation.

text: デボルさんとポポルさんの罪を責めるなんてできない
translation: I can't blame Devola and Popola for any wrongdoing.

vocabulary.meaning: to blame, to criticize, to condemn

grammar: ~なんてできない expresses 'I can't possibly do something like ~'. なんて adds a sense of 'something like that' with a dismissive or incredulous nuance.

text: カイネたちの立場を知ろうともしなかった
translation: I didn't even try to understand Kaine's situation.
grammar: ~ようともしなかった means 'didn't even try to'. The volitional ~よう + とも + しない is an emphatic negative.

text: 俺も同じなんだから
translation: Because I'm the same way.
grammar: ~なんだから gives an explanatory reason with emotional emphasis - 'because (after all) I'm the same'.

text: カイネとエミールに謝ろう / 謝って
translation: I'll apologize to Kaine and Emil. / After apologizing...
grammar: ~よう is the volitional form expressing intention ('let's' or 'I'll'). 謝って is the te-form, here trailing off to indicate continuation.

text: いや 謝ったって
translation: No, even if I apologize...
grammar: ~たって is a casual form of ~ても meaning 'even if'. It expresses that even the action wouldn't change the outcome.

text: この子は
translation: This child...
grammar: この子は with trailing は suggests an unfinished thought about someone.

text: カイネさんとまたお話ができて
translation: Being able to talk with Kaine again...
grammar: ~ができて is 'being able to do' in te-form, connecting to the next clause to express what results from this ability.

text: 僕 嬉しいです
translation: I'm so happy.

text: そうか / 私もだ / カイネさんを助けるために
translation: I see. / Me too. / In order to save Kaine...

vocabulary.meaning: to help, to save, to rescue

grammar: ~ために expresses purpose - 'in order to'.

text: 僕 頑張ったんですよ / 一生懸命磨いてみたり お湯をかけてみたり
translation: I tried really hard, you know. / I tried polishing you, pouring hot water on you...

vocabulary.meaning: to do one's best, to work hard
to polish, to brush, to shine

grammar: ~てみたり...~てみたり lists multiple things tried. ~てみる means 'to try doing'. ~んですよ adds explanation with emphasis.

text: お湯をかけたのか
translation: You poured hot water on me?
grammar: ~たのか expresses surprised confirmation of past action.

text: はい でも全然ダメで
translation: Yes, but it didn't work at all.
grammar: 全然 with ダメ means 'completely useless/didn't work at all'.

text: 石化を解いてくれてありがとう エミール
translation: Thank you for undoing the petrification, Emil.

vocabulary.meaning: to undo, to release, to solve

grammar: ~てくれてありがとう expresses gratitude for someone doing something for you. ~てくれる indicates the action benefited the speaker.

text: ちょっとだけ姿が変わっちゃいましたけど
translation: My appearance changed a little, though...
grammar: ~ちゃいました is casual polite form of ~てしまいました, expressing that something happened (often with regret or unexpectedness).

text: 辛い思いをさせてしまったな
translation: I made you go through something painful.
grammar: 辛い思いをする is an expression meaning 'to have a painful experience'. ~させてしまう is causative + regret - 'ended up making (someone) do'.

text: でもこの姿も悪いことばかりじゃありません
translation: But this form isn't all bad.
grammar: ~ばかりじゃない means 'not only ~' or 'not all ~'. It negates the idea that something is exclusively negative.

text: こうしてカイネさんを見ながらお話できるようになりましたし
translation: Now I can talk while looking at you, Kaine.
grammar: ~ようになる means 'to become able to' or 'to come to do'. ~ながら indicates simultaneous actions. ~し at the end suggests there are additional reasons.

text: そうだ
translation: That's right. / Oh!
grammar: そうだ can mean 'that's right' (agreement) or be an interjection when remembering something.

text: カイネさんのこと聞かせてくれませんか
translation: Could you tell me about yourself, Kaine?
grammar: ~てくれませんか is a polite request form - 'won't you please do ~ for me?' 聞かせる is causative of 聞く - 'to let/make (someone) hear'.

text: 私の話はつまらないぞ
translation: My story is boring, you know.
grammar: ぞ is a masculine emphatic particle, giving a warning or assertion. Kaine uses masculine speech patterns.

text: カイネさんのこと もっと知りたいんです
translation: I want to know more about you, Kaine.
grammar: ~たいんです is the explanatory form of wanting to do something, adding emotional emphasis to the desire.

text: わかった
translation: Alright. / I understand.
grammar: Plain past わかった used for agreement or acceptance.

text: 私に魔物がつく前 / 子供の頃の話だ
translation: Before the Shade possessed me... / A story from when I was a child.
grammar: ~がつく means something attaches/possesses. 子供の頃 means 'childhood' or 'when I was a child'.

text: 私は少し変わった体をしているせいで / 村では厄介者として扱われていた
translation: Because my body was a little different... / I was treated as a nuisance in the village.

vocabulary.meaning: to treat, to handle, to deal with

grammar: ~せいで indicates a negative cause - 'because of ~'. ~として means 'as'. ~られていた is passive continuous past.

text: でもただ一人 / おばあちゃんだけが私を受け入れてくれたんだ
translation: But only one person... / Only Grandma accepted me.
grammar: ~だけが emphasizes exclusivity - 'only ~ (and no one else)'. ~てくれた shows the action was done for the speaker's benefit.

text: どんなに辛いことがあっても / おばあちゃんがいてくれるだけで私は生きようと思えた
translation: No matter how hard things got... / Just having Grandma there made me want to live.

vocabulary.meaning: to be able to think, to feel like

grammar: どんなに~ても means 'no matter how ~'. ~ようと思える is 'to be able to feel like doing' (volitional + potential of 思う).

text: カイネさんにとって本当に大切な人なんですね
translation: She was truly precious to you, wasn't she?
grammar: ~にとって means 'for (someone)' or 'to (someone)'. ~なんですね seeks confirmation while showing understanding.

text: そうだ カイネさんの石化も治ったんですから
translation: That's right, since Kaine's petrification was cured...

vocabulary.meaning: to be cured, to heal, to recover

grammar: ~んですから gives an explanatory reason with emphasis - 'since/because ~'.

text: 魔物つきのことや僕の体を治す方法も見つけましょう
translation: Let's find a way to cure the Shade possession and fix my body too.

vocabulary.meaning: Shade possession, being possessed by a Shade
to cure, to fix, to heal

grammar: ~ましょう is the volitional polite form - 'let's do'. ~や indicates 'and' when listing things non-exhaustively.

text: みんなで探せばきっと簡単ですよ
translation: If we all search together, I'm sure it'll be easy.
grammar: ~ば is the conditional form - 'if ~'. みんなで emphasizes doing something together as a group.

text: 僕たちならきっとできると思います
translation: I believe we can do it.

vocabulary.meaning: can do, to be able to

grammar: ~なら is a conditional meaning 'if it's ~' or 'as for ~'. ~と思います expresses one's opinion or belief.

text: お湯をかけるよりは難しいと思うがな
translation: I think it'll be harder than pouring hot water, though.
grammar: ~より is used for comparison - 'more than ~'. ~と思うがな is masculine speech adding a wry or teasing nuance - 'I think, but...' Kaine is gently teasing Emil.

text: もうそのことは忘れてください
translation: Please forget about that already.
grammar: ~てください is the polite request form. もう adds emphasis - 'already' or 'now'.

text: 眠れたのか
translation: Did you sleep? / Were you able to sleep?

vocabulary.meaning: to be able to sleep (potential form)

grammar: ~たのか asks for confirmation about a past action, with concern or curiosity.

text: 目が赤いな
translation: Your eyes are red.
grammar: The sentence-ending な adds a tone of noticing or mild concern.

text: あまり思い詰めるな / ポポルさんたちのところに行く
translation: Don't think too hard about it. / I'm going to see Popola and the others.

vocabulary.meaning: to brood over, to worry excessively, to think too hard

grammar: ~るな is the negative imperative (prohibition) - 'don't do ~'. This is masculine/direct speech. ~のところに行く means 'to go to where (someone) is'.

text: 分かった
translation: Got it.

text: こんにちは デボルさん
translation: Hello, Devola.

text: よう / 意外だな / もう声をかけてもらえないかと思ってた / いいえ あれは村のためだと分かっています
translation: Hey. / I'm surprised. / I thought you wouldn't talk to me anymore. / No, I understand that was for the village.

vocabulary.meaning: to speak to, to call out to, to address

grammar: ~てもらえない is the negative potential of ~てもらう - 'unable to have someone do'. ~かと思ってた means 'I thought (wondering if)'. ~のためだ means 'it's for the sake of'.

text: デボルさんたちの立場だったら仕方ありません
translation: If I were in your position, it couldn't be helped.

vocabulary.meaning: can't be helped, inevitable, no choice

grammar: ~だったら is past conditional - 'if it were'. 仕方ありません is the polite form of 仕方がない.

text: そうだな / じゃあポポルの元にも行ってくれ
translation: I see. / Then please go see Popola too.

vocabulary.meaning: place where someone is, under someone's care

grammar: ~てくれ is a casual/masculine request form - 'please do ~ for me'. ~の元に means 'to where someone is'.

text: 魔王のことで話があるそうだ / ええ 今から会いに行きます
translation: She says she has something to tell you about the Shadowlord. / Yes, I'll go see her now.
grammar: ~そうだ (hearsay) means 'I hear that, they say that'. 会いに行く is 'to go to meet' - purpose + motion verb.

text: それと / なんだ / 俺も 昨日は取り乱してすみません
translation: Also... / What? / I'm sorry for losing my composure yesterday.

vocabulary.meaning: to lose composure, to be upset, to be flustered

grammar: ~てすみません apologizes for having done something.

text: お前が謝る必要はないさ / 誰だって仲間を傷つけられると腹が立つ
translation: You don't need to apologize. / Anyone would get angry when their friends are hurt.
grammar: ~必要はない means 'there's no need to'. 誰だって means 'anyone'. ~られると (passive + と) means 'when ~ is done to someone'. 腹が立つ is an idiom for getting angry.

text: 彼女たちにも謝っておいてくれ / ちゃんと伝えておきます
translation: Apologize to them for me too. / I'll make sure to tell them.

vocabulary.meaning: to tell, to convey, to pass on

grammar: ~ておく means to do something in advance or for future benefit. ~ておいてくれ is a request to do this.

text: ポポルさん
translation: Popola...

text: 昨日はごめんなさい
translation: I'm sorry about yesterday.
grammar: 昨日は at the beginning sets the context for what the apology is about.

text: どうして あなたは何も悪くないわ
translation: Why? You didn't do anything wrong.
grammar: 何も...ない means 'nothing'. The わ at the end is a feminine sentence-ending particle.

text: でもポポルさんたちも悪くない
translation: But you and Devola aren't wrong either.
grammar: ~も悪くない means 'also not wrong' or 'not at fault either'.

text: 村のみんなのためなのに辛く当たってしまった
translation: Even though it was for everyone in the village, I was harsh.

vocabulary.meaning: to be harsh toward, to treat harshly

grammar: ~のに means 'even though, despite'. ~てしまった expresses regret about a completed action. 辛く当たる is an expression meaning to treat someone harshly.

text: 優しいのね / ありがとう 気にしないで
translation: You're kind. / Thank you. Don't worry about it.

vocabulary.meaning: to worry about, to mind, to care about

grammar: ~のね is a feminine sentence pattern expressing realization or gentle confirmation. 気にしないで means 'don't worry about it'.

text: そういえば何か話があるとか聞いたのだが
translation: By the way, I heard you had something to tell me.

vocabulary.meaning: speaking of which, by the way, now that you mention it

grammar: ~とか聞いた means 'I heard something like'. ~のだが is Weiss's archaic speech - modern would be ~んだけど. This is a characteristic pattern showing his old-fashioned manner.

text: ええ
translation: Yes.

text: 石の神殿があったでしょ / 我のいたところだな
translation: You know the Stone Shrine? / That's where I was.
grammar: ~でしょ is casual form of ~でしょう, seeking confirmation. 我 (われ) is Weiss's archaic first-person pronoun - highly characteristic of his old-fashioned speech. Modern speakers would use 私 or 僕.

text: そう 魔王の居所はそこと繋がっているらしいの
translation: Yes, the Shadowlord's lair is apparently connected to that place.

vocabulary.meaning: to be connected, to be linked

grammar: ~らしい indicates hearsay or inference - 'apparently, seems like'. The の at the end is feminine.

text: 灯台元暮らしか / でもあそこに渡る橋は通れなくなってるんじゃ
translation: It's darkest under the lighthouse (right under our noses)... / But isn't the bridge to get there impassable now?

vocabulary.meaning: it's darkest under the lighthouse (idiom: overlooking what's right in front of you)
to be able to pass (potential form)

grammar: 灯台元暗し is a proverb meaning you often miss what's closest to you - like not seeing what's right under your nose. ~なくなっている means 'has become unable to'. ~んじゃ is casual contraction of ~のではないか, suggesting a question/concern.

text: 船で行けばいいわ / 船
translation: You can go by boat. / Boat?
grammar: ~ばいい means 'should just ~' or 'it would be good to ~'. It suggests a simple solution.

text: ようやく交易用の水路が整備されたの
translation: The trade waterways have finally been prepared.

vocabulary.meaning: for use, for the purpose of

grammar: ~用 suffix means 'for ~ use'. 整備される is passive - 'to be prepared/developed'.

text: 魔物からの被害もあってずいぶんと遅くなってしまったけど
translation: It was delayed quite a bit due to damage from monsters.

vocabulary.meaning: to be late, to be delayed

grammar: ~からの被害 means 'damage from ~'. ~もあって means 'there was also ~' (as a contributing factor). ~てしまった expresses regret about the delay.

text: 石の神殿の裏側の道にも船を出してくれるよう頼んでおいたわ
translation: I've asked them to send boats to the path behind the Stone Shrine too.

vocabulary.meaning: to put out, to send out

grammar: ~よう頼む means 'to ask (someone) to do ~'. ~ておく indicates doing something in preparation/advance.

text: 船頭さんに言えば無料で使わせてくれるはずよ
translation: If you tell the boatman, he should let you use it for free.
grammar: ~ば言えば is conditional - 'if you tell'. 使わせてくれる is causative + くれる - 'will let (you) use'. ~はず indicates expectation - 'should, ought to'.

text: これで街の間の移動も楽になると思うんだけれど
translation: I think this will make traveling between towns easier.
grammar: ~の間 means 'between'. ~になる means 'to become'. ~と思うんだけれど trails off modestly.

text: ありがとうございます
translation: Thank you.

text: ポポルさんにはお世話になりっぱなしだよ
translation: We're always in your debt, Popola.

vocabulary.meaning: to be indebted to, to receive someone's care/help

grammar: ~っぱなし means 'continuously, all the time (often implying excess or negligence)'. お世話になりっぱなし means 'constantly receiving help/being in debt'.

text: 本当に感謝してる
translation: I'm truly grateful.

text: じゃあ 行ってきます / 気をつけてね 本当に 気をつけて
translation: Well then, I'm off. / Take care. Really, take care.

vocabulary.meaning: I'm off, I'll go and come back
to be careful, to take care

grammar: 行ってきます is the standard phrase when leaving somewhere you'll return to. 気をつけて is the te-form used as a request - 'take care'. The repetition emphasizes genuine concern.
